title: Are you scared of falling in love? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s the unknown. I’m not even sure I know the difference between beong seriously infatuated and being in love. I’m not even sure I’ve ever been truly in love. Sure, I had weak knees and my heart raced before, but to me it looked a lot like fear, and as it turned out, I was right to be afraid. I had a couple of relationships with people I “just loved”, but wasn’t in love with, some of them went terribly south. I never lied about my feelings but I learned people are very willing to say they can accept your feelings (or lack thereof) just to be close to you, this doesn’t mean they don’t behave horribly once they feel safe. I was seriously infatuated two, maybe three times. I never told them. They claimed they love me, but I knew this can’t be true: people like them don’t love, not very deep anyway. Or at least that’s what I got from their behavior. I can get easily interested in nice, goodhearted people, and I’m open to relationships with them, but chances are, when my heart starts jumping you’re probably fucked up and dangerous in one way or another. I think I have detected the pattern, and it’s always been like this, so far: I “fell in love” with people who were abused and hadn’t learned to go from survivor to transformer. I stole this from Andrew Vachss with whom I agree on that it isn’t enough to survive. Well it’s a lot better than dying, but there has to be more. It feels like “home” with these people. It feels like we know eachother since a long time. It’s scary, not only because we remember what home was like. And we know we’ll never be safe. Whatever I do, I know there is a monster behind the corner. I won’t let that monster into my bed deliberately. Not until it dresses up in a tutu and sings “You are so beautiful to me” anyway.

Love is transformative. It’s almost an afterthought in fairytales…it’s the reward. The ultimate goal. I am, at my heart, a romantic. Not in the Hallmark movie way (although, I wouldn’t know…I’ve never watched one) and not in a Disney way. I am a romantic with little patience for schmaltz. I want to be an Arthur Rackham illustration. This one was always one of my favorites…I have a thing for exotic raven-haired beauties. Prophetically, it’s from Bluebeard. Google Image Result for https://www.honeyandwaxbooks.com/pictures/1002135.jpg?v=1534745542 You know the story of Bluebeard,right? The young wife marries a rich man and she is given a set of keys to the house. There is one key she is warned not to use. It is the key to the room in the cellar. She is nearly blinded by curiosity and when her husband leaves, she sneaks down to the cellar and opens the door. The room in the cellar is filled with all of the corpses of the women that came before. Horrified, she slams the door and locks the room. Somehow, magically, there is a bloodstain on the key she can’t rub off. She can’t unsee the horror. The story is not about the villain. It’s about that moment when curiosity becomes a burden. The story is, of course, about more than that. It’s about loss of innocence. We start out so open and free, then life happens. We collect wounds and scars. It can go a few different ways…we can become bitter and wounded, or we get frightened of ugliness. Arthur Rackham illustrations never become bitter. They are noble and good - arcane, fierce, wild and free. They are beautiful. I am a modern person. I live in modern times and modern places that are uglier than I like to imagine. I translate some of that ugliness into my personal mythos. I have experiences I can’t un-live. I think I’ve fallen one time too many. It’s too hard…or maybe it’s not. This last time threw me down, hard. I’m having a hard time getting back up. I want to be that open, lovable ingenue I was. I am the heroine in my own story. We are all heroes and heroines, slightly tragic, in our own imaginations. I try…just not very hard. I’m not an ingenue anymore. That’s why I’m afraid.

The girl who looks beautiful or the handsome hunk .You know the problem with people now a days is that they love a person on the basis of his/ her looks.I usually ask people why are thay in a relationship with someone…. that is the so called gf and bf relation and are they going to be with that person for the rest their life .Most people don't agree on that and say the reason why they are with person is that their other friends are also in a relationship and they don't want to be single.Just because it has beacome a fashion and show off. It may seems like I am bragging. But what to do I am an old soul in this new world . Not scared of love ……love is love …..but only if understood properly. Be you❤

To be honest, the heart will find it really difficult to be vulnerable again, to be able to trust again, to be able to speak freely without holding back again, without being open again, without being able to express everything you think again, without being the OLD YOU again. The heart always wants what it wants. If you truly love someone that true love will never go. You will try to learn to live with that pain, time will lessen the pain though it may never heal completely. You may never be foolish again in love. Second time being in love requires courage. It requires being able to trust again and being vulnerable again. It requires strength to break that wall that you would have built around yourself, your heart. But it is more mature. It is not to replace the true first love. This time around it will be more mature and more understanding. It may or may not happen again, but your heart will learn to live with that pain. First time, it took me a second, to love my mom. Second time, it took me a few seconds, to have a crush. Third time, it took me a few minutes, my crush during third grade of school. Fourth time, it took me few hours, my crush at college. Fifth time, it took me months, My first true love. Got heart broken because it was unrequited, but still loving unconditionally, got my self-respect bruised, lost some so called mutual “friends”, misunderstood by many, hurt myself, and so on. So finally, it takes forever, to fall in love again.

It’s not about the end but the journey itself. Since there have been so many answers from adults already, I will answer this from my own perspective, a 17 years old teenager. Am I affraid of falling in love? Absolutely not. As a teenager, I believe the best thing that can happen to me is getting into a relationship. I feel wonderful to fall in love with someone. I don’t know why so many people afraid of their end of a relationship but never thought about the journey they got together. I had a girl friend once and you know what, that was the most valuable memory I’ve got. Falling in love taught me many things from that one relationship and whenever I look back, there is not a single place for regret. It will eventually end someday? Screw it. The experiences that a relationship can endure you are far more worthy than the pain you feel when your relationship ends. Yes, it may feel extremely suck for a week or two (maybe a month or even more), by the time you get over it, you will see significant changes in you and your mindset. I’m not afraid of how falling in love can desperate me, I respect every moments that I fall in love.

Why, because we have doubts and fears from our past because we refuse to leave past behind and recycling the garbage of our past, now allowing the universe to write us a new story. We are also stopping love because of our ego, anger, hurt and who said what, like I was. At the of the day, Love has no room for what said what, pointing fingers, all it is asking for remove all those who this person is and what I am doesn’t matter, stop blocking the heart with pride and arrogance, and the need to be right. All love wants is to love you without the armour and the swords, all stripped bared and vulnerable, so are you prepared to be naked (TW James).

Imagine the happiest moment in your life. Now imagine that moment lasting longer than an instant, but rather weeks, months, or even years into the foreseeable future. This is part of what love is like. You think and plan the future with that significant other, life is great until… Your SO breaks up with you for whatever reason. All your intense happiness immediately transforms into intense sadness. You could feel this way for weeks, months, or years into the foreseeable future. This is some of the effects of love. Love is to be respected Edit: the answer to your question is based on the individuals willingness to risk vulnerability for that amazing experience. I am not scared as the reward is worth the risk. Hopefully this gives insight as to why some people are scared

And one thing that i firmly believe is “what’s meant to be, is bound to happen no matter what” so don't be scared,take a leap of faith and experience the most beautiful emotion of this world . response.answer_text: Fear. Quite obviously that is the best answer to your question. When you love you risk everything in your life. Your career, your future, social life everything. If the risk pays off all of the aforementioned will take quantum leaps in their respective fields. Contrary to the same if it doesn’t you may experience stagnancy along with a gradual decline. Which if not kept under check may reach disasterous levels. That is what makes me scared of falling in love. However at this point before i conclude i would just like to state something that i have found after taking the abovementioned risks again and again. Love is the only thing that can heal the wounds that love itself has bestowed.

Yes. I have issues that no one knows or would be the wiser about. I am afraid to let myself be truly happy and letting anyone get super close to me. I am extremely introverted. i often find myself looking for love. But the second it becomes real, I run away.

No. There is no reason to be scared of love. However… if you assume “love” means finding/having someone on whom you rely to fulfill your needs, then it is reasonable to be scared of “love”. That other person will likely fall away at some point in time, as all forms and conditions in this universe are temporary. If you then still rely on that person for your happiness, you will suffer.

Yes of course. Anyone can be afraid of falling in Love. Reasons of fear can be many - fear of unknown, fear of heartbreak, apprehensions of not making right choice, fear of commitment, and the list goes on. But operating from the place of fear is not Love. This 4 letter word is largely misunderstood. Attachment is not love. but if you love you will get attached. Falling in love or getting in love is easy, It takes courage to be in love. All the best :)

Of course. Falling in love is a big deal. It affects your whole being, which can be both an exhilarating and exhausting feeling. And there can be implications, depending on whether you decide to accept the love and enter into a relationship. One is probably more likely to be afraid when it's the first serious relationship. Or, say you fall in love with a married person, or someone in your workplace, these are complications that can be very tricky.

That being said, as a single person I would advise strongly to fall in love, to open yourself to falling in love and never to be scared of falling in love. As the saying goes: "'Tis better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all."
